title-group.article-title: A projection algorithm for partial eigenvalue assignment problem using implicitly restarted Arnoldi method

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Science and Mathematics, Suez Canal University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Mohamed A Ramadan, Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, Menoufia University, Egypt Email: mramadan@eun.eg

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The problem of reassigning a part of the open-loop spectrum of a linear system by feedback control, leaving the rest of the spectrum invariant, is called the partial eigenvalue assignment problem. In this paper, a projection method based on a direct use of the implicitly restarted Arnoldi method for the partial eigenvalue assignment problem in linear control systems is presented. The method is of interest in common situations where the system is very large and only a few of its eigenvalues need to be assigned. Numerical examples are given to display the performance and the accuracy of the proposed algorithm.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Consider the linear-time invariant multi- input control system (1)x·=Ax+Bu where A is a large n×n real non-symmetric constant matrix, B is an n×p matrix, x is an n-column state vector and u is a p-column control vector. The eigenvalue assignment problem (EAP), more commonly known in control theory as the pole assignment problem, is the problem of choosing a feedback matrix F, by substituting u=-Fx into (1.1), such that the closed loop system x·=(A-BF)x has a desired set of poles (the matrix A-BF has a desired set of eigenvalues). This problem is very useful in many applications in the study of control systems (for example to maintain stability to the system (1.1). It is known that (Wenham, 1979), the EAP has a solution if and only if the pair (A,B) is controllable. In single input case, F is unique when it exists.

The above problem is studied through the conventional numerical methods (e.g. the implicit QR and real Schur methods as in Mimins and Paige (1981) and Patel and Misra (1984). However, in control problems of large and sparse structures it is often desirable to modify only a few of the eigenvalues of the open-loop system and leave the rest unchanged.
Such a problem is called the partial EAP.

This problem is considered in the literature see for example Datta and Saad (1991), Lu et al. (1991), Datta B. N. and Datta K. (1990) and Ramadan (1995) where the technique proposed by Datta and Saad (1991) first solves a Sylvester- type equation AX-XH=GC where H is an upper Hessenberg matrix constructed using Arnoldi's algorithm such that the spectrum of H is {μ1,μ2,…,μm}, the matrix G is of the special form G=(0,0,…,0,b) and X is an orthonormal matrix obtained from the orthonormal matrix V constructed from Arnoldi's algorithm where VTAV=H, by multiplying X by a chosen scalar. The Sylvester-type equation is then rewritten in an equivalent form so that the matrix X will be the basis of the invariant subspace of A, and the required feedback vector f=Xem, where em=(0,0,…,0,1)T so that spectrum of (A-bfT) will contain {μ1,μ2,…,μm}. The techniques in the methods (Saad, 1988; Ramadan, 1995) are similar and depend mainly on the notion of computing an orthonormal basis, using the Arnoldi algorithm as in Ramadan (1995) or using partial Schur QR factorization as in Saad (1988) of an invariant subspace associated with the eigenvalues that are needed to be assigned. There then needs to be the application of one of the known and suitable methods to solve a resulting associated EAP of a smaller dimension. Similarly, in the work due Lu et al. (1991) the partial pole assignment problem for large scale systems is also addressed, beside to the eigenvectors assignment, introducing similar projection technique.

However, the drawback of these methods is that in the case of using the Arnoldi algorithm, the computed eigenvalues of the Hessenberg matrix not only those with largest real parts but those with largest modulus. Also, the use of partial Schur QR factorization may destroy the sparsity and the structure of the system matrix A

sec.title: 2.1. The partial eigenvalue assignment problem
sec.p: For the sake of simplicity the single-input time invariant system is considered (2.1)x·=Ax+bu where b is an n-column vector, and u is a scalar. Now, let λ1,λ2,…,λm,λm+1,…,λn be the eigenvalues of A where m<<n and {λj}j=1n are invariant under complex conjugation. The problem of reassigning a part of spectrum of A, leaving the rest of the spectrum invariant is called the partial eigenvalue assignment. Applying a state-feedback control u=-fTx into (2.1) yields a closed loop system (2.2)x·=(A-bfT)x

The problem is to find a vector f such that (2.3)λ(A-bfT)={μj}j=1m∪{λj}j=m+1n where {μ1,μ2,…,μm} are suitably chosen numbers. Here λ(A) denotes the spectrum of the matrix A. Throughout this paper, it is assumed that the set {λj}j=1n are invariant under complex conjugation with negative real part except a few eigenvalues {λj}j=1m of A with nonnegative real part. The problem is considered of replacing a set of a few eigenvalues {λj}j=1m of A by a set {μj}j=1m that real or mixed eigenvalues with negative real part.

sec.title: 2.2. The implicitly restarted Arnoldi method (IRA)
sec.p: The implicitly restarted Arnoldi method (IRA) proposed by Sorenson (1992), is one of the most effective restarting method to compute some of the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a non-symmetric matrix. This method combines Arnoldi factorization with the implicitly shifted QR Algorithm to determine an Arnoldi factorization of the form: (2.4)ATVm=VmHm+ηmemT that satisfies (2.5)λ(Hm)={λ1,λ2,…,λm}wherenorm(ηm)is tiny
The basic steps of the IRA are stated. A detailed discussion of the IRA method is given in Sorenson (1992) and Radke (1996).
1.Consider a k -step of Arnoldi decomposition (Saad, 1988) to the matrix AT with an arbitrary initial unit vector v1 to determine the decomposition of the form: (2.6)ATVk=VkHk+ηkekT
2.Compute the spectrum of Hk : λ(Hk)={γ1,γ2,…,γk}.
3.Sort the eigenvalues {γj}j=1k of Hk as follows (2.7)Rel(γ1)≤Rel(γ2)≤…≤Rel(γp)<0 ≤Rel(γp+1)≤…≤Rel(γk) such that p is the number of eigenvalues of Hk with negative real part.

4.Apply p steps of the shifted QR to the decomposition (2.6) using {γj}j=1p, resulting in the new factorization (2.8)ATVk+=Vk+Hk++ηkekTQ where Vk+=VkQ, Hk+=QHHkQ and Q=Q1Q2…Qp, where Qi is associated with factoring (H-γiI)=QiRi, i=1,2,….P and k=m+p. It turns out that the first m-1 entries of ekTQ are zero, so that a new m -step Arnoldi factorization can be obtained by equating the first m columns on each side: ATVm+=Vm+Hm++ηm+emT

5.Extend a p -step Arnoldi factorization to a k=m+p -step Arnoldi factorization (2.9)ATVk+=Vk+Hk++ηkekT 6.Restart the previous process with new initial unit vector v1+=Vk+e1 until (2.10)ATV=VH,λ(Hm)={λ1,λ2,…,λm}andnorm(ηm) is tiny where {λj}j=1m be a few eigenvalues of A with nonnegative real part.

sec.title: 2.3. Some needed lemmas and algorithms to assign eigenvalues in a Hessenberg matrix
sec.p:
Some lemmas and algorithms are stated to assign eigenvalues in a Hessenberg matrix that are needed throughout the paper. Definition 1: Datta and Saad (1991)
Let M∈Rm×m be an arbitrary m×m matrix and b∈Rm be a column vector. The pair (M,b) is said to be controllable if rank(b,Mb,M2b,…,Mm-1b)=m. Lemma 1: Datta and Saad (1991)
Let M be an arbitrary m×m matrix and b be a column vector such that pair (M,b) is controllable. If X satisfies (2.11)XM=MX
Then (M,Xb) is controllable if and only if X is nonsingular. Lemma 2: Datta and Saad (1991)
Let H∈Rm×m be an unreduced upper [lower] Hessenberg matrix such that it commutes with X ; that is (2.12)XH=HX
Then X is nonsingular if and only if (H,Xe1=x1)([H,Xem=xm]) is controllable. Lemma 3. Datta BN and Saad Y (1991)
Let H∈Rm×m be an unreduced lower Hessenberg matrix and let x1,x2,…,xm be the m successive columns of a matrix X that commutes with H.
Then
xm can be chosen arbitrarily
The columns xm-1 through x1 can be computed recursively from:
(2.13)xi=1hi,i+1(Hxi+1-Σj=i+1mhj,i+1xj),i=m-1,m-2,…,3,2,1

sec.title: 3. Algorithms for eigenvalue assignment in a Hessenberg matrix
sec.p: In this section an outline to simple recursive algorithms is given to assign eigenvalues, real or mixed, in a Hessenberg matrix. This problem of assigning eigenvalues in a Hessenberg matrix is considered by many authors. Among these methods the conceptually easy and simple algorithm introduced by Datta (1987) for a real eigenvalue assignment case and Ramadan and Elshazly (2004) where mixed eigenvalues are assigned by modifying Datta algorithm. The problem is also considered, in the general form: (HT,c), in Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010) where it is carried out by modifying both algorithms in Datta (1987) and Ramadan and Elshazly (2004). In the following two subsections, the problem is to find a feedback vector g1 such that the special form HT-emg1T has the desired set of eigenvalues {μ1,μ2,……,μm} real (Datta, 1987) or mixed (Ramadan and Elshazly, 2004) where HT is an unreduced lower Hessenberg matrix and em is the last column of the m×m identity matrix I.

sec.title: 3.1. Algorithm for the eigenvalues assignment problem in a Hessenberg matrix: real case (Datta, 1987)
sec.p: Starting with controllable pair (HT,em) where H=(hij) is an m×m unreduced upper Hessenberg matrix and em is the last column of the m×m identity matrix I.

The main idea of the method is to construct a nonsingular matrix L and compute a feedback vector g1 such that HT-emg1T=(LT)-1ΛTLT, where Λ is a bidiagonal matrix with eigenvalues that need to be assigned. The method constructs a set of vectors {lk}k=1m where l1=(1,0,…,0)T is given such that the m×m matrix L=[l1,l2,…,lm] will be nonsingular matrix through the algorithm given as: Algorithm 1: Datta (1987)
Step 1
Construct a set of normalized vectors l1=(1,0,…,0)T
For i=1,2,…,m-1 do l~i+1=(H-μiI)li; li+1=l~i+1 ‖l~i+1 ‖; lm+1=(H-μmI)lm
Step 2
Compute g1=lm+1/k ; where k is the last entry lm.
In the following the theorem is stated, which will be used in the suggested method, and an outline of its proof presented Theorem 1: Datta (1987)
The modified matrix HT-emg1T has the desired spectrum {μ1,μ2,……,μm}.
For proof see Datta (1987).

sec.title: 3.2. Algorithm for the eigenvalues assignment problem in a Hessenberg matrix: mixed case (Ramadan and Elshazly, 2004)
sec.p:
Starting with controllable pair (HT,em) where H is an unreduced upper Hessenberg matrix and em is the last column of the m×m identity matrix I. The problem is to find a feedback vector g1 such that the modified matrix HT-emg1T has the set of eigenvalues {μ1,μ2,…,μ2t,μ2t+1…,μm} of mixed eigenvalues where the first 2t numbers are complex together with their complex conjugation in {μj}j=1m while the others {μ2t+1,…,μm} are real distinct numbers. The main idea of the method is to construct a nonsingular matrix L and compute a feedback vector g1 such that HT-emg1T=(LT)-1ΛTLT, where Λ is a bidiagonal matrix with {μj}j=1m as its eigenvalues needed to be assigned. This method avoids complex arithmetic by replacing the bidiagonal matrix Λ by a novel approach of real Schur matrix form with 2×2 bumps corresponding to each pair of complex conjugate eigenvalues, which preserve the nonsingularity of L and the modified matrix HT-emg1T has the same the set of eigenvalues {μj}j=1m. The method constructs a set of vectors {lk}k=1m where l1=(1,0,…,0)T is given such that the m×m matrix L=[l1,l2,…,lm] will be nonsingular matrix through the algorithm: Algorithm 2: Ramadan and Elshazly (2004)
Step 1 Setj=1, l1=(1,0,…,0)T
For i=1,3,…,2t-1 set l~i+1=(H-Re(μj)I)li li+1=l~i+1 ‖l~i+1 ‖ l~i+2=(H-Re(μj)I)li+1, li+2=l~i+2 ‖l~i+2 ‖
Define: y=(Im(μj))2 ‖l~i+1 ‖ ‖l~i+1 ‖li
Set li+2=li+2+y j=j+1;
End
Step 2
For i=2t+1,…,m-1 do l~i+1=(H-μiI)li; li+1=l~i+1 |l~i+1 |;
End
Step 3
Compute lm+1=(H-μmI)lm
Step 4
Compute g1=lm+1/k ; where k is the last entry lm. Theorem 2: Ramadan and Elshazly (2004)
The modified matrix HT-emg1T has the specified set of mixed eigenvalues {μj}j=1m.
For prove of the theorem see Ramadan and Elshazly (2004).

sec.title: 3.3. Algorithm for the eigenvalues assignment problem in a Hessenberg matrix: general case (Ramadan and El-Sayed, 2010)
sec.p:
It is known from theorems 1 or 2 that if the vector em is replaced with an arbitrary vector c, the constructive proof of these theorems cannot be applied. A modification is necessary. The algorithm considered in Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010) is a remedy to this case. Given an unreduced upper Hessenberg matrix H and b be an arbitrary column vector. Introduce the vector c=VTb method with the property that (HT,c) is controllable where V is the orthonormal column matrix obtained from the IRA. The method is to find a vector g such that matrix HT-cgT has the desired set of eigenvalues {μ1,μ2,……,μm} real or mixed. The algorithm is as follows: Algorithm 3: A Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010)
Stage 1
The two steps of Algorithm 1 are carried out.
Stage 2:
Find a matrix X such that HTX=XHT. This can be done by setting the last column xm=c and compute the columns xm-1 through x1 using the recursive relations (2.13).
Stage 3:
Solve for g: XTg=g1.
Note that the system has a unique solution (since X is nonsingular). Algorithm 3-B: Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010)
Stage 1:
The four steps of algorithm 3 are carried out.
Stage 2:
Solve for g: XTg=g1.where X is the matrix constructed in stage 2 of algorithm 2.
The following theorem is a slight modification of method of Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010). Theorem 3: Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010)
The modified matrix HT-cgT has the specified set of eigenvalues {μ1,μ2,……,μm}.
For the proof of the theorem see Ramadan and El-Sayed (2010).

sec.title: 3.4. Proposed algorithm for partial eigenvalue assignment problem
sec.p: In this section a simple and efficient technique of the partial EAP for the system (2.1) is presented. The IRA method is applied to the matrix AT to compute an Arnoldi decomposition of the form (2.4), such that norm(ηm)≥0 is tiny and λ(Hm) is a good approximation of the set {λj}j=1m of eigenvalues of A.
where (4.1)ATV=VH,VTV=Im,andnorm(ηm)is tiny for upper Hessenberg matrix H with spectrum (4.2)λ(H)={λj}j=1m
Here Im denotes the m×m identity matrix.
Let the matrix pair {H,V} satisfies (4.1) and (4.2). Introduce the vector c=VTb and consider the problem of determining a vector g, such that (4.3)λ(HT-cgT)={μj}j=1m
This EAP is referred to as the projected EAP. The matrix-vector pair (HT,c) is said to be controllable if (4.4)rank(HT,c)=m

A direct application of algorithm 2, the vector g is obtained. Finally, a feedback vector f will be formed such that the spectrum of the closed-loop system x·=(A-bfT)x contains {μ1,μ2,…,μm}. If f of the form f=Vg is chosen, where V is the matrix obtained from the IRA, the required result is obtained. Namely λ(HT-cgT) is contained in λ(A-bfT). The above proposed technique for solving the partial EAP can be summarized in the following theorem, which is a slight modification of theorem of Saad (1988) and Ramadan (1995). Theorem 4.1
Let g be constructed so that the matrix (HT-cgT) has the spectrum {μ1,μ2,…,μm} and let the vector f be chosen of the form f=Vg. Then the matrix A-bfT has the set of eigenvalues {μ1,μ2,…,μm,λm+1,…,λn}. Proof
Let W be the remaining eigenvectors of AT associated with the remaining eigenvalues {λj}j=m+1n. In other words, W is an orthonormal basis of the orthogonal complement of span{V} and is such that the matrix S=(V,W) is orthogonal. Using ATV=VH, and VTV=Im, since WTV=0 and VTATV=H.
Then (4.5)WTATV=WTVH=0
These identities show that the matrix AT is similar to the block- triangular matrix STATS=(HVTATW0WTATW)
It follows from (4.2) that (4.6)λ(WTATW)={λj}j=m+1n
Assume that f=Vg satisfies the partial EAP (2.3). The above identities and WTf=0 yield VT(A-bfT)TV=VTATV-VTfbTV=H-gcT, where c=VTb and g=VTf VT(A-bfT)TW=VTATW-VTfbTW=VTATW-gE where E=bTW WT(A-bfT)TV=WTATV-WTfbTV=0, WT(A-bfT)TW=WTATW-WTfbTW=WTAW and therefore ST(A-bfT)TS=(H-gcTVTATW-gE0WTATW) and the following is obtained (4.7)ST(A-bfT)S=(HT-cgT0WTAV-ETgTWTAW)
It follows from (4.6) and λ(HT-cgT)={μj}j=1m that λ(ST(A-bfT)S)={μ1,μ2,…,μm,λm+1,…,λn}.
Thus, g satisfies the projected EAP (4.3) and the theorem is then proved.

The application of the IRA method for partial eigenvalue assignment is summarized in the following algorithm. Algorithm 4: Partial eigenvalue assignment using the IRA method
Apply the implicitly restart Arnoldi method to the matrix AT to compute an Arnoldi decomposition of the form (2.4), such that norm(ηm)≥0 is tiny, H is upper Hessenberg matrix and λ(Hm) is a good approximation of the set {λj}j=1m of eigenvalues of A.
Solve the projected EAP for the controllable pair {HT,c} where c=VTb. That is, to determine the vector g such that λ(H-gcT)={μj}j=1m. This means that the eigenvalues {λj}j=1m of A will be replaced with {μ1,μ2,…,μm} real or mixed.
Form the required feedback solution vector f=Vmg to the partial EAP for the pair (A,b).

This algorithm is analogous to the projection algorithms proposed in Saad (1988) and Ramadan (1995). It differs from them in its use to the IRA method. The IRA method is often very effective at determining the eigenvalues {λj}j=1m and the associated invariant subspace of AT. The computation of g in step 2 of algorithm 4 can be accomplished by the algorithm 3 described in sections 3.

sec.title: 4. Numerical examples
sec.p: Numerical examples are considered to test the performance of the algorithm 4, where a MATLAB program to carry out the computations of the examples is written using a MATLAB version 5.3. In numerical examples, the projected eigenvalue problem HT-cgT is solved to determine the vector g such that λ(HT-cgT)={μj}j=16 where the arbitrary set {μj}j=16 are real numbers as shown in example 1 or mixed (real and invariant under complex conjugation) with negative real part as shown in example 2.

sec.title: 4.1. Example 1 (Real case)
sec.p: Consider a randomly generated matrix A such that A∈R200×200 is a large non-symmetric constant matrix.
Eigenvalues of A under complex conjugation with positive real parts are found to be λ1,2=0.9963∓0.2017i;λ3,4=0.9884∓0.4066i;λ5,6=0.9871±0.9586i
The remaining eigenvalues are under complex conjugation with negative real parts.
Stage 1:
The IRA is applied.
First:
k=30 steps of the Arnoldi factorization to the matrix AT are applied with an arbitrary initial unite vector v1 to determine the decomposition ATV30=V30H30+η30e30T
The upper Hessenberg matrix H30 so determined had 24 eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ24 with negative real part and six eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ6 with positive real part.
Second:
The eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ24 are applied as shifts in the IRA method as described in section 2, to obtain Arnoldi decomposition (2.9).
Third:
The Arnoldi process was restarted as described in section 2 several times (two times) to obtain the decomposition. ATV6=V6H6+η6e6T,wherenorm(η6)=2.5329e-013
The upper Hessenberg matrix H6 is
Columns 1 through 4
Columns 5 through 6
Stage 2:

The projected eigenvalue problem HT-cgT was solved to determine the vector g such that λ(HT-cgT)={μj}j=16 where c=VTb, V6×200 is computed as shown in IRA in stage 1 and b be an arbitrary column vector. The arbitrary set {μj}j=16 of negative real numbers was introduced. {μj}j=16={-0.4960,-0.7729,-0.0382,-0.2022,-0.7380,-0.9865}
Stage 3:
f=Vmg was introduced where the vector f is the computed solution of the partial EAP. λ(A-bfT)={μj}j=16∪{λj}j=7200
Finally:
The remaining 194 eigenvalues of A∈R200×200 and (A-bfT) are remain unchanged. The first ten eigenvalues of A∈R200×200 and (A-bfT) for the remaining eigenvalues are shown in Table 2.

sec.title: 4.2. Example 2 (Mixed)
sec.p: Consider a randomly generated matrix A such that A∈R100×100 is a large non-symmetric constant matrix. Eigenvalues of A are under complex conjugation with positive real parts are found to be λ1,2=0.9942∓0.2499i;λ3,4=0.9846∓0.2727i;λ5,6=0.9783∓0.3040i.
The remaining eigenvalues are under complex conjugation with negative real parts.
Stage 1:
The IRA was applied.
First
k=30 steps of the Arnoldi factorization were applied to the matrix AT with an arbitrary initial unite vector v1 to determine the decomposition ATV30=V30H30+η30e30T
The upper Hessenberg matrix H30 has 24 eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ24 with negative real part and six eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ6 with positive real parts.
Second:
The eigenvalues γ1,γ2,…,γ24 were applied as shifts in the IRA method as described in section 2, to obtain Arnoldi decomposition (2.9).
Third:
The Arnoldi process was restarted as described in section 2 several times (two times) to obtain the decomposition. ATV6=V6H6+η6e6T where norm(η6)=1.0561e-10 the upper Hessenberg matrix H6 is
Columns 1 through 4
Columns 5 through 6
Stage 2:

The projected eigenvalue problem HT-cgT was solved to determine the vector g such that λ(HT-cgT)={μj}j=16 where c=VTb, V6×100 is computed as shown in the IRA in stage 1 and b be an arbitrary column vector. The arbitrary set {μj}j=16 of numbers real and mixed were introduced {μj}j=16=[-1.0000-0.9800i-1.0000+0.9800i-1.3000-0.9700i-1.3000+0.9700i-0.9800-1.5000]
Stage 3:
f=Vmg was introduced where the vector f is the computed solution of the partial EAP. λ(A-bfT)={μj}j=16∪{λj}j=7100.
Finally:
The remaining 94 eigenvalues of A∈R100×100 and (A-bfT) remain unchanged. The first ten eigenvalues of A∈R100×100 and (A-bfT) for the remaining eigenvalues are shown in Table 4.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p:
The purpose of this paper was to show how the IRA method can be put to work to solve the partial EAP in large-scale control problems. In general cases, these problems are practically significant where only a small number of system eigenvalues need to be reassigned, keeping the remaining large number of good eigenvalues invariant. The numerical examples considered show that the proposed algorithm is numerically viable and computationally accurate for large systems. The numerical results show that the spectrum of the matrix HT-cgT produced by algorithm 3 is closer to the set {μj}j=1m (real or mixed) where c=VTb and V is computed as shown in IRA in step 1 from algorithm 4. Thus, the proposed technique shows that λ(A-bfT)={μj}j=1m∪{λj}j=m+1n with b is an arbitrary column vector as required Table 1. Table 1.

DattaBNSaadY (1991) Arnoldi methods for large Sylvester-like observer matrix equation and partial pole placement. Linear Algebra and its Applications 154–156225–244.
